newsitem.title: JAPAN: Teenager arrested in brutal Japan slaying of boy.
newsitem.headline: Teenager arrested in brutal Japan slaying of boy.

text.p: A 14-year-old seeking revenge on Japan's strict education system confessed on Saturday to strangling an 11-year-old acquaintance and beheading him in a crime that shocked the nation, police said.

The head of the boy was found at the gates of a junior high school in this western Japan city on May 27 with a rambling note stuffed in his mouth that said in part: "Well, this is the beginning of the game...it's great fun for me to kill people."
The killing of the boy, Jun Hase, shocked the nation, not only for its brutality but also because the victim was in a special education program for children with learning problems.
The killer's writings also put a harsh spotlight on an educational system that instils great pressures to succeed.
"The suspect and Jun Hase are believed to be acquaintances", Seishi Yamashita, a detective at the Hyogo Prefectural Police, said in a televised news conference on Saturday night.

"We searched intensively around the site of the murder and asked the 14-year old suspect to accompany us to the station. The suspect confessed to committing the murder. We found a knife at his house," Yamashita said.
Police said they are still questioning the youth for a motive.

But in a letter to a local newspaper a week after the body was found, the killer said that he would murder three people a week to "take revenge on the compulsory education system." No other deaths have since been linked to the murder.
"I am not forgetting revenge for the compulsory education that has produced me as an invisible existence and on the society that has produced this compulsory education."
Education Minister Takashi Kosugi said in Tokyo on Saturday that authorities would investigate whether there was any link between the killing and the education establishment.
Police said the letter provided important leads in identifying the alleged killer.

The severed head and body of the victim were found three days after he left home to visit his grandfather, who lived a few blocks away. The body was found dumped in a forest near a television transmission facility.
Since the killing, children in the area have been armed with noise-emitting devices and walk to school with adult escorts, a rare measure in a country renowned for its low rate of violent crime.

The arrest comes just a few days after police said they had few leads in the case. They had looked into a possible Internet connection to the crime after similar words to those used by the killer were found on a public bulletin board.
But police did not say on Saturday whether the Internet leads had produced anything.
Police sources told NHK television that among the strongest clues were the finding of headless pigeons and cats with amputated legs in the neighbourhood where Hase and the suspect lived.
